dt.t: Celebrities often feed off the {wi}adulation{/wi} of fans, but that acclaim can be fleeting and illusory.
During the campaign, he basked in the {wi}adulation{/wi} of his fans and emphasized the promises that drew the biggest applause and the most retweets …
… she thought he'd be an egomaniac, spoiled by fame and public {wi}adulation{/wi}.
… is only starting to reach the level of popular and critical {wi}adulation{/wi} that bands work their entire lives to achieve …
He had not fully understood his achievement until he returned home to an outpouring of {wi}adulation{/wi} from local media.

et: Middle English {it}adulacioun{/it} "insincere praise, flattery," borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}adūlātiōn-, adūlātiō,{/it} from {it}adūlārī{/it} "to fawn upon (of dogs), praise insincerely" (of uncertain origin) + {it}-tiōn-, -tiō,{/it} suffix of verbal action

On the presumption that it is a denominal verb, Latin {it}adūlārī{/it} has been compared with Sanskrit {it}vāla-, vāra-{/it} "hair of a horse's tail, horsehair," Lithuanian {it}valaĩ{/it} "horse's tail," though this is difficult both semantically and phonetically. More recently, the base of Latin {it}avidus{/it} "greedy, eager" has been proposed as a source (see {et_link|avid|avid}), via a prefixed {it}*ad-awido-,{/it} syncopated to {it}*ad-audo-,{/it} then with the second {it}d{/it} dissimilated to {it}l,{/it} yielding {it}*adūlo-,{/it} "eagerly seeking something, flattering."
shortdef: extreme or excessive admiration or flattery
